awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of the Keck Cosmic Web Imager Reionization Mapper
awd_abstract_narration:
While astronomical images can offer breathtaking records of the appearance of the Universe, far greater information is obtained by dividing a light beam according to color (a technique known as spectroscopy).  This approach can yield important details about the physical properties of the source: its temperature, chemical composition, density, mass, and velocity, among others.  Constructing very efficient, wide spectral coverage, high-resolution mapping spectrographs is therefore an effective approach to getting the most from our very largest ground-based telescopes.  Dr. H. Lewis (California Association for Research in Astronomy together with the California Institute of Technology and the University of California) proposes to complete the development of the Keck Cosmic Web Imager spectrograph for the 10-m Keck II telescope atop Mauna Kea, Hawaii with new optics optimized for the red portion of the spectrum.  The final instrument will provide an extraordinary platform for carrying out sensitive assessments of galaxy formation and evolution in the first few hundred million years after the Big Bang, to study the interstellar medium in external galaxies, to probe star clusters and nebulae in our own Milky Way galaxy, and to track the process of star formation within those clusters.

The Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI) is designed to provide seeing-limited visible band, integral field spectroscopy with moderate to high spectral resolution (up to R = 20,000), selectable slicer scales and fields of view, high efficiency, and excellent sky subtraction. KCWI will benefit from the Keck II telescope's large, 10-m aperture and excellent site, providing a dual-channel, modular implementation. The blue channel of KCWI is nearly complete; the red channel to be funded through this proposal will extend the spectral coverage to the entire optical window from 3500 to 10500 angstroms and enable scientists to address several of the key questions relating to the process of the formation and evolution of external galaxies, and thereby of the development of matter in the universe.

Funding for the development of the red channel of the Keck Cosmic Web Imager is being provided by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences through its participation in the Major Research Instrumentation program.

por.por_cntn:
The Keck Cosmic Reionization Mapper (KCRM) is the red-optimized (530 to 1050 nm) channel of the Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI), a facility class instrument in high demand at the W. M. Keck Observatory (WMKO). The KCRM project was an upgrade for KCWI and had project goals of extending the KCWI integral field spectroscopic capabilities to address a broad range of science that are responsive to key science goals in past and current decadal surveys. With the upgrade, KCWI distinguishes itself from other instruments with its extraordinary flexibility: simultaneous spectroscopy across the entire visible spectrum with a wide field and configurable spectral resolution as high as R~20,000 in some modes. KCWI with KCRM will provide increased capabilities for the observation of the kinematics and spatial distributions of emission line sources in star forming regions, the study of jets, outflows, stellar populations, and the connection between galaxies and their dark matter halos and provide increased sensitivity for radial velocity studies aimed at detecting low mass black holes.


The upgrade included a new dichroic, grating exchanger, articulation stage to set the wavelength range of interest, camera optics, fold mirror, and detector system. These additions were designed and fabricated at Caltech, UCSC, and WMKO. Lab assembly occurred on the Caltech campus before the components were shipped to WMKO for integration into the instrument inside the summit clean room facility. A graduate student at UCSC was involved with the detector system development and detector characterization. A second Caltech graduate student was involved with the assembly, integration, testing and commissioning of KCRM. Both students worked on-site at the WMKO summit and base facility.


The upgraded KCWI completed First light on 1 June 2023 followed by several engineering activities to test and characterize the performance. KCWI was returned to service in August 2023 and is again available to the US community of astronomers for routine nighttime science operations. Under the umbrella of WMKO’s data services initiative, KCRM was delivered with a DRP and KCWI’s blue channel DRP was upgraded to open source python with both DRPs delivering reduced data in near real time to the Keck Observatory Archive for community use. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: John O'meara
